reviewText:
This 2 Disc DVD set contains 13 episodes from the classic Scooby-Doo cartoon. Amazon doesn't always do a good job on their DVD episode listings so here are the episodes that are included in this DVD set:

Disc 1:
1. Scooby-Doo! and the Spooky Scarecrow
2. Who's Afraid Of The Big Bad Werewolf
3. A Gaggle of Galloping Ghosts
4. Which Witch is Which?
5. A Tiki Scare Is No Fair
6. Scared a Lot in Camelot
7. Hang in There, Scooby-Doo

Disc 2:
1. Snow Job Too Small
2. The Stoney Glare Stare
3. Scooby Doo and a Mummy, Too
4. A Scooby-Doo Halloween
5. Scoobra Kadoobra
6. Scooby In Kwackyland

Please note, early pre-release info indicated that "A Halloween Hassle at Dracula's Castle, Parts 1 and 2" were originally scheduled for release on this DVD set, but were switched with the "Scooby Doo and a Mummy, Too" and "A Scooby-Doo Halloween" episodes before final release.

Grade: B+
Entire family: Yes
1969-2015, 272 min. (13 cartoons), Color
Not rated (would be G, easily)
Warner Bros.
Aspect ratio: Varies (see below)
Featured audio: Dolby Digital 2.0
Bonus features: N/A
Trailer/Amazon link

Scooby-Doo! and the Beach Beastie is a brand-new 22-minute cartoon and the sixth direct-to-DVD offering of its kind. But when you compare this latest effort with the filler added to flesh out the two-disc Scooby-Doo! 13 Spooky Tales: Surfs Up, Scooby-Doo!, you almost wish that Warner Bros. had substituted a few more older episodes instead. Beach Beastie is by far the weakest, a going-through-the-motions affair that relies too much on Freds paranoia over nets and Scoobys new love interest. It also offers too little in the way of mystery and phony monster momentsthe two driving forces behind the popular franchise. What we get this time is a water monster that weve seen too many times before in other films.

Though a few voiceover actors and the style of drawing and animation changed over the years, the formula remains mostly the same: the Mystery, Inc. gang (timid Great Dane Scooby-Doo, always hungry Shaggy, bookish Velma, stylish Daphne, and All-American guy Fred) rambled onto the scene where a monster or ghost was terrifying people. Sometimes they were hired to get to the bottom of things, while other times they helped out a friend or simply fell into a mystery while trying to take a vacationoften to some exotic location. And always the unmasking revealed a phony monster with someone inside or with a remote control manipulating it for revenge or personal gain.

I don't know if Warner Bros. deliberately chose filler episodes from a full range of Saturday-morning Scooby-Doo! cartoon shows, but to me that variety is the chief bonus. You really get a sense of the whole arc of this franchise. If only Warner Bros. had arranged the episodes in order, so viewers could better see how the characters and the series developed over 40 years. As is, the episodes are arranged either thematically (if you're a glass half-full person) or randomly (if half-empty).

Heres the breakdown of whats included, which Ive arranged chronologically according to the TV series on which the episodes first appeared:

Scooby-Doo! Where Are You!
A Clue for Scooby-Doo (1969)
Scoobys Night with a Frozen Fright (1970)
A Creepy Tangle in the Bermuda Triangle (1978)
The Creepy Case of Old Iron Face (1978)

Scooby-Doo and Scrappy-Doo
Shiver and Shake, That Demons a Snake (1979)
Twenty Thousand Screams under the Sea (1979)

The Richie Rich/Scooby-Doo Show
Hang in There Scooby (1980)
Scooby-Nocchio/Scoobys Roots/Lighthouse Keeper Scooby (1981)
Excaliber Scooby/Scoobys Luck of the Irish/Scoobys Escape from Atlantis (1981)

A Pup Named Scooby-Doo
Scooby Dude (1988)

Whats New Scooby-Doo?
She Sees Sea Monsters by the Seashore (2002)

Shaggy & Scooby-Doo Get a Clue!
Cruisin for a Bruisin (2007)

NewDirect to DVD
Scooby-Doo! and the Beach Beastie (2015)

ScoobyDooSurfsUpscreenScooby and the Mystery, Inc. gang somehow appeal to all ages, no matter what generation you're from. In that respect its a true family cartoon series.

Scrappy-Doo appears in a few of these episodes, which will either annoy or delight viewers. Most of the episodes are in 1.33:1 aspect ratio, while some are 1.37:1 and others are 169 widescreen. The picture quality varies according to age, with the sharpest (Beach Beastie) pictured as a screen shot.

Only one episode actually involves surfing, but the cartoons included on this DVD all have something to do with the sea. Diehard fans will want to buy complete seasons only, but for families whose interest is more casual, Scooby-Doo! 13 Spooky Tales: Surfs Up, Scooby-Doo! offers a nice sampler of the Scooby-Doo! franchise over the decades.

FamilyHomeTheater.com

Surf's up was a major disappointment and did not live up to its potential.  no surfing at all, and most of the film in a resort.  The gang never get out of their old outfits.  The cover never happens.  The only positive thing is the collection of old episodes that I'm happy to have.

This is a great DVD. Here is the episode list.

Featured Episodes:
1) Scooby-Doo! and the Beach Beastie (brand-new 22-minute cartoon) (NEW)

2) A Clue for Scooby-Doo (Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!) (Available on Scooby Doo, Where Are You!  The Complete First and Second Seasons)

3) Scooby's Night with a Frozen Fright (Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!) (Available on Scooby Doo, Where Are You!  The Complete First and Second Seasons)

4) Scooby Dude (A Pup Named Scooby-Doo) (Available on A Pup Named Scooby Doo Complete 1st Season)

5) Scooby-Nocchio/Scooby's Roots/Lighthouse Keeper Scooby (The Richie Rich/Scooby-Doo Show) (NEW TO DVD)

6) Excalibur Scooby/Scooby's Luck Of The Irish/Scooby's Escape From Atlantis (The Richie Rich/Scooby-Doo Show) (NEW TO DVD)

7) Cruisin' for a Bruisin' (Shaggy & Scooby-Doo Get A Clue!) (NEW TO DVD)

8) Hang in There Scooby (The Richie Rich/Scooby-Doo Show) (Available on Scooby-Doo! 13 Spooky Tales Run for Your 'Rife!)

9) The Creepy Case of Old Iron Face (Scooby's All-Stars) (Available on Scooby Doo, Where Are You!  The Complete Third Season)

10 A Creepy Tangle in the Bermuda Triangle (Scooby's All-Stars) (Available on Scooby Doo, Where Are You!  The Complete Third Season)

11) She Sees Sea Monsters by the Sea Shore (What's New, Scooby-Doo?) (Available on What's New Scooby-Doo?: Season 1)

12) Shiver and Shake, That Demon's a Snake (Scooby-Doo and Scrappy-Doo) (Available on Scooby-Doo: 13 Spooky Tales Around the World)

13) Twenty Thousand Screams Under the Sea (Scooby-Doo and Scrappy-Doo) (Will be on SCOOBY-DOO! AND SCRAPPY-DOO!:
THE COMPLETE SEASON 1)

I have enjoyed each of these new episodes released on these 13 Spooky Tales DVDs. And they have been a great venue for Warner Bros to test the waters on unreleased cartoons featuring Scrappy Doo. After all these decades I am so over my disdain for Scrappy. And it is really great to be able to see these again.

Shaggy and Scooby Doo Get A Clue has the best Scooby theme songs ever and is a fun different take on Scooby Doo. It is similar to The Venture Brothers, only not disturbing. It is great to get another episode of it.

So we get 1 New episode and 3 New to DVD episodes and one episode that became available the month before. Not bad for these 13 Spooky Tales releases.

UPDATE:

Just got this in the mail today.

The DVD opens with a trailer for Tom & Jerry Spy Quest and where the Tom & Jerry movies seem to be aimed at a younger audience than the Scooby Doo releases, I am beyond excited about the return of Johnny Quest and the character designs of the Quest characters is very interesting, seems a little inspired by John K. Seeing this trailer made my day.

Scooby-Doo! and the Beach Beastie: I really like the design of the water monster, and love that Fred and nets is more or less a thematic holdover from Mystery Inc.

Scooby-Nocchio/Scooby's Roots/Lighthouse Keeper Scooby: Starts off with a quick take on Pinocchio, then moves onto a ghost of a lighthouse keeper that messes with the laws of physics, and ends with a visit to another dog in the Scooby Doo family, Grandpa Scooby.

 Excalibur Scooby/Scooby's Luck Of The Irish/Scooby's Escape From Atlantis: This one starts with a minotaur, a statue of a giant four-armed cyclops, and crazy enough, a guy at a party wearing a creepy horse head mask. Next Scooby, Scrappy and Shaggy are menaced by an evil Merlin. And last they cross an angry leprechaun.

Cruisin' for a Bruisin': A stressed out Dr. Phibes takes a vacation to get away from the Dog und Hippy Boy and ends up on the same cruise with Shaggy and Scooby Doo.

Yes, once again, we get another new themed compilation of both already-on-DVD and NEW-to-DVD Scooby-Doo episodes. This time the theme is Halloween. First, to clarify the number of episodes on this set. Even though they advertise 13 episodes (3 of which are NEW-to-DVD), there's really only 11, plus 1/2, plus 1/3 shows (2 and 1/2 of which are NEW-to-DVD). For those of you who are trying to piece-meal together all the remaining Scooby-Doo episodes on DVD, here are the specifics of what's new and what's not (and available elsewhere): Disc 1: 1. Scooby-Doo! and the Spooky Scarecrow - (BRAND-NEW) complete 2013 half-hour direct-to-video Halloween special. Scheduled to premiere on Cartoon Network sometime in October, 2013. 2. Who's Afraid of the Big Bad Werewolf - originally aired during the 1970-1971 Season 2 of "Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!". Available on Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!: The Complete 1st and 2nd Seasons. Complete half-hour show. 3. A Gaggle of Galloping Ghosts - originally aired during the 1969-1970 Season 1 of "Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!". Available on Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!: The Complete 1st and 2nd Seasons. Also available on Scooby-Doo's Spookiest Tales. Complete half-hour show. 4. Which Witch Is Which - originally aired during the 1969-1970 Season 1 of "Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!". Available on Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!: The Complete 1st and 2nd Seasons. Also available on Scooby-Doo's Spookiest Tales. Complete half-hour show. 5. A Tiki Scare Is No Fair - originally aired during the 1970-1971 Season 2 of "Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!". Available on Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!: The Complete 1st and 2nd Seasons. Complete half-hour show. 6. Scared a Lot in Camelot - originally aired during the 1976-1977 Season of The Scooby-Doo/Dynomutt Hour - The Complete Series. Complete half-hour of "The Scooby-Doo Show" syndicated version. 7. Hang in There, Scooby-Doo - (NEW-to-DVD) originally aired during the 1977-1978 Season of the two-hour-long "Scooby's All-Star Laff-a-Lympics". Complete half-hour of "The Scooby-Doo Show" syndicated version. Disc 2: 8. Snow Job Too Small - originally aired during the 1982-1983 Season of the hour-long "The Scooby and Scrappy-Doo/Puppy Hour". The Scooby-Doo half-hour portion of the show was composed of three (3) seven minute shorts. This short is just 1 of the 3 shorts that made up the Scooby half-hour. Available on Scooby-Doo!: 13 Spooky Tales - Holiday Chills and Thrills. No opening credits. Closing credits only. 9. The Stoney Glare Stare - (NEW-to-DVD) originally aired during the 1984-1985 Season of "The New Scooby-Doo Mysteries". Second half of the half-hour show, but with BOTH the opening and closing credits. 10. Scooby-Doo and a Mummy, Too - originally aired during the 1969-1970 Season 1 of "Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!". Available on Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!: The Complete 1st and 2nd Seasons. Complete half-hour show. 11. A Scooby-Doo! Halloween - originally aired as a 2004 half-hour Halloween special on The WB network during the 2003-2004 Season 2 of "What's New, Scooby-Doo?". Available on What's New, Scooby-Doo? Volume 6 - Monster Matinee and as a Bonus episode on What's New, Scooby-Doo? The Complete 2nd Season. Complete half-hour show. 12. Scoobra-Kadoobra - originally aired during the 1985-1986 Season of The 13 Ghosts of Scooby-Doo! - The Complete Series. Complete half-hour show. 13. Scooby in Kwackyland - originally aired during the 1985-1986 Season of The 13 Ghosts of Scooby-Doo! - The Complete Series. Complete half-hour show. There are no Special Features in this set. And it's important to NOTE, that regardless of what other websites may say, and what earlier reviews have said, the episodes A Halloween Hassle at Dracula's Castle Parts I and II from the 1984-1985 Season of "The New Scooby-Doo Mysteries" are NOT on this DVD set. As much as I enjoyed this brand-new 2013 Halloween episode, this set has the fewest number of new-to-DVD Scooby episodes of all the recent 13 Spooky Tales compilation sets. And to make matters worse, they repeated one episode from the last set released. Fortunately, the next 13 Spooky Tales set - Ruh-Roh Robot will reverse the trend. And as a Halloween themed set, there were other Halloween episodes that could and should have been included, like the aforementioned A Halloween Hassle at Dracula's Castle, or The Headless Horseman of Halloween. And for you Scrappy-haters, there are only 4 out of the 13 episodes that feature him, only one of which is new. So, if you are a Scooby-Doo completist, then this set is recommended for you. But, if you are trying to get the most bang for your buck of new episodes, then you are better off to continue waiting for better compilations or possible complete series sets of the remaining series. If nothing else, at least I hope this set gets us one step closer to getting a complete series release of the 1984-1985 Season of "The New Scooby-Doo Mysteries".
My kids and pets love Scooby doo, we love Scooby and we are trying to get all their shows etc. Thanks for having this one.

This Dvd set is garbage except for the new episode it is not worth it. a hassle at dracula's castle is not even on here instead warner brothers ripped off the consumers again and added a Scooby doo Halloween from what's new Scooby doo instead of it. If I did not open this I would have returned it.

Alright I love classic scooby doo a bunch. I buy every unreleased classic episodes from the 70's-80's, not to say I don't buy modern scooby shows and movies but the classics were and always will be my favorites. Warner brothers are really being a pain in the neck with there releases of 80's scooby in particular becuase of scrappy doos inclusion in all the shows. I still enjoy these however and like to see them slowly but surly geting released. The particular episode from The New Scooby Doo Mysteries (1984) A Halloween Hastle in Dracula's Castle is a favorite of mine even though evey monster is real. Why I wasn't so crazy about this set is because i already own most of the episodes on this one, but warner bros. still gets my business for the I few I don't own. I am a really hardcore collector so technically if you just casually pick a few DVD's up here and there for your kids/family this collection will be just fine because most if not all the episodes will be new to you. However hardcore collectors shoud look trough the episode list below  before buying.

1. Scooby-Doo! and the Spooky Scarecrow
2. Who's Afraid Of The Big Bad Werewolf
3. A Gaggle of Galloping Ghosts
4. Which Witch is Which?
5. A Tiki Scare Is No Fair
6. Scared a Lot in Camelot
7. Hang in There, Scooby-Doo
8. Snow Job Too Small
9. The Stoney Glare Stare
10. A Halloween Hassle at Dracula's Castle, Part I
11. A Halloween Hassle at Dracula's Castle, Part II
12. Scoobra Kadoobra
13. Scooby In Kwackyland

Overall most of the episodes could pass off as halloween episodes though not actually taking place at halloween time other than the very misplaced A Tiki Scare is no Fair, Snow Job to Small, and Hang in There, Scooby-Doo ,Snow Job to Small released in the Winter/Christmas set so that one being on this set is rediculous,
Hang in There, Scooby-Doo on the other hand hasn't been released so even though it dosn't feel like a halloween episode it's inclusion makes the set more worth the buy. I'm really looking foward to the new halloween special on the set.

Overall, they could've rereleased some actual Halloween episodes, or find other new releases instead of episodes released in so many other collections. 3/5

Great mix! Iknow can get them in full seasons but there are some from one show titled "the Scooby Doo Show" which I have yet top find on DVD so that is good.

Scooby Doo has a lot of Halloween-themed mysteries, but only a couple of them surfaced here (and one other in the Around the World set). But it's still worthy of owning alongside the other 13 Spooky Tales sets, even though it has 1 repeat from the Christmas set (Snow Job Too Small). It even features 2 episodes of The 13 Ghosts of Scooby Doo, and the 2003 Halloween special (A Scooby Doo Halloween), and an all-new one from 2013 when this set was released (The Spooky Scarecrow)! At least 3 of the feature-length Scooby Movies took place on or around Halloween, sold separately of course, as of Spring 2017; those being The Ghoul School, The Goblin King, & Frankencreepy! Be sure to add Run for Your Rife to your 13 Spooky Tales sets, or your holiday collections, today! "Scooby-Dooby-Doo!"

This DVD collection has an added security feature that caused an incredible headache for me. The only way to play them is to unhook my ENTIRE home theater system and only hook up the DVD player to the t.v. That means no speakers, cable, t.v. converter, game systems, ect. can be hooked up in order to get these stupid DVD's to properly play! I understand the purpose of this is to make it more difficult to reproduce the DVD, but to make me have to go through all that for a scooby doo DVD is ludicrous. Ridiculous
